awd_titl_txt: The Interplay Between Membrane Structure and Protein Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Protein-membrane interactions are key events in processes as diverse as immunology and neurobiology, as they are the means by which information flows across the cell membrane. Thus protein-membrane interactions are the key to intercellular communication in multicellular organisms. While much work has been done to define what features of membrane -binding proteins confer specificity for their targets, the role of membrane lipid composition in these highly precise interactions is less well understood. In this research project, the PI will develop a comprehensive framework for understanding how the properties of the membrane impact protein-lipid recognition events. The complexity of the systems to be studied requires a truly multidisciplinary approach. With techniques and ideas adapted from molecular immunology, neurobiology, membrane physical chemistry, and interfacial X-ray scattering, this program will provide a unique training opportunity for the next generation of interdisciplinary scientists. Research opportunities will extend to qualified high school and undergraduate students. Concepts in interdisciplinary science will be brought to school children through the outreach activity “Physics with a Bang!” 
 
Regulation of protein-membrane interactions is governed in part by the specificity of peripheral membrane proteins for specific lipids. However, there appears to be a diverse landscape of parameters encoded into membranes that is dynamically controlled by the cell, offering distinct but correlated avenues to affect protein binding to membranes and subsequent functions. The work will address two fundamental questions: (1) How is information embedded in the composition and structure of lipid membranes properly recognized and distinguished by peripheral membrane-binding proteins? and (2) What is the relationship between membrane curvature and membrane tension in determining the binding behavior and subsequent function of proteins traditionally thought to be membrane curvature-sensing? For the former goal, the PI will largely focus on proteins that recognize phosphatidylserine phospholipids in the outer leaflet. For the latter goal, interactions with proteins that utilize amphipathic alpha helical motifs such as those found in alpha-synuclein will be studied. It is hypothesized that both classes of proteins employ sensitivity to differences in membrane properties and geometry to mediate their differential recognition properties. Thus, the primary focus of this research is to establish such sensitivities of their binding to fundamental physiochemical membrane parameters.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

In this granting period, we have used monolayers, spherical nanoparticle-supported bilayers and unilamellar vesicles as model systems, and a suite of biophysical and structural techniques coupled with molecular dynamic simulations to provide new perspectives on the molecular mechanism by which membrane properties influence interactions with membrane-associating proteins. We have addressed two fundamental questions on how information embedded in the composition and structure of membranes is recognized by peripheral membrane-binding proteins, and what the relationship between membrane curvature is in determining the binding behavior and subsequent function of proteins traditionally thought to be 'membrane curvature-sensing'. These questions touch on two important classes of proteins, peripheral membrane-binding proteins and what have been thought of as 'membrane curvature-sensing' proteins; elucidation of these questions is fundamental to our understanding of how the membrane context is utilized for protein recognition and the subsequently finetuning of protein binding.

The immune system uses the recognition of host cells, which expose phosphatidylserine (PS) lipids extracellularly, by protein receptors (i.e., PS receptors) that peripherally associate with membranes. We have established the sensitivity of two PS-receptors, transmembrane immunoglobulin and mucin domain (TIM) proteins (calcium-mediated binding) and milk fat globular epidermal growth factor 8 (MFG-E8; calcium-independent), to membrane parameters in their differential recognition of membranes for their proper physiological functions. Using a combination of fluorescence binding assay, x-ray reflectivity and molecular dynamics simulation, we elucidate the detailed mechanism of TIM/lipid interactions by resolving subtle structural differences among them at a high level of atomic accuracy not typically achievable in protein/membrane interactions, and reveal the role membrane plays in the differential recognition of the TIM proteins. Our study has been extended to include both murine and human TIM proteins and our comparative study reveals similarities and differences in their binding behaviors. Even though MFG-E8 has a single binding interface with the membrane, our work reveals that this peripheral membrane-binding protein has three binding modes, each associated with a different number of PS, with the cooperativity of MFG-E8 binding being enhanced by the availability of negatively charged lipids. Such analysis is made possible by a theoretical model developed in this granting period that describes the dependence of peripheral proteins on lipid composition through an analytic expression for their association, and introduces the Membrane-Hill number as a measure of membrane-based cooperativity. This model coupled with the refined methodology we developed for obtaining membrane-bound protein affinity and structure has the potential for much broader applicability with respect to unraveling atomistic details of other membrane-binding proteins.

We have used alpha-synuclein (aSyn) as a representative of 'membrane-curvature sensing' proteins. A number of membrane parameters have been identified to promote aSyn binding such as negative charge and lipid packing defects, particularly defects produced through membrane curvature. However, the latter is often considered secondary to the protein's preference for the former. While negative charge increases the density of aSyn bound to a membrane, it alone is not sufficient for aSyn binding. Our study instead shows that lipid packing defects alone are. Our work further reveals a packing defect-dependent shift in the ensemble of bound conformations of the protein favoring the insertion of the second helix, which is further away from the N-terminus. Our examination of eight disease-associated single point mutations of aSyn shows that all mutants exhibit a shift in the equilibrium bound state away from the N-terminal helix toward the second helix. Altogether, our results indicate that disruption to the equilibrium binding of the two alpha helices of aSyn could play a role in disease progression. 

Broader Impacts

The research activities have provided training opportunities for researchers in a highly interdisciplinary area, and help train the next generation of interdisciplinary research scientists. The project has served to enhance the content of a graduate course in membrane biophysics, as well as the curriculum development of an interdisciplinary degree-granting program in Biophysical Sciences.

Apart from graduate students and postdocs, research opportunities in the PI's laboratory have been extended to qualified high school, undergraduate, and summer research students. The PI has run a 7-week summer research program, placing 10-15 rising high school seniors from the University of Chicago Laboratory Schools in laboratories across the Biological Sciences Division and the Physical Sciences Division at the University of Chicago to catalyze the interest of these young students in a career in science. The PI has hosted high school and undergraduate students for research. Science, especially the concept of interdisciplinary science, has been brought to school children through outreach activities, including Physics with a Bang!, an annual Holiday Show and Open House.
